reviewText: After his sister Charlotte is kidnapped by Indians, Sam decides to try to find her himself. With promises of gold, he lures Russian (Richard Boone) along on the trip, and they head into the Utah desert, encountering hostile Apaches, and discovering what seems to be a lost tribe who enjoy their human sacrifices. Sam and Russian are captured, and Sam must pass an impossible endurance test to save his sister's life.The main problem with this film is its general air of hokeyness. Boone tries to make his character so "colorful," that he overacts more than a room full of Gabby Hayes clones. His character is given a rather unglorious sendoff in the surprise finale, and he misses the big climax of the film. The rest of the cast tries, but the direction is very amateurish and the script is weak. Many scenes drag on forever, with characters repeating plot points again and again. The kidnapping tribe's origin and identity is never explained, and the one Native American who can speak English comes off like a robot version of Sacheen Littlefeather. The film also runs into the age old problem many action films run into. The journey to find Charlotte is so perilous, but the glossed-over return trip home seems to have gone without a hitch.Watch for the very unconvincing day for night scenes and grainy stock footage scattered throughout. I cannot recommend "Against a Crooked Sky," although its heart seems to be in the right place.This is rated (PG) and contains physical violence, some gun violence, mild profanity, and very brief female nudity.
summary: Earl Bellamy's Against a Crooked Sky

reviewText: This is a nice, uncomplicated film about a boy whose older sister is kidnapped by Indians of a type never seen in the area.  Because it is largely his fault that she was taken, he decides to go after the sister, hunting for the unknown Indians as he goes.  Along the way, he meets the usual Western characters and finally ends up "racing the sun" across a valley to help his sister.  I've watched this a bunch of times and always enjoy it.  It's about in the same genre as "Across the Great Divide" and "Seven Alone"(which also stars Stewart Peterson, if memory serves) as well as "Where The Red Fern Grows" and makes a good family movie to watch.  Perhaps some of it is a stretch to believe, but it's enjoyable and you really don't mind.

reviewText: I just saw this again for the first time since I was a kid, and I think it's that nostalgic factor that makes this one so tough to call because, yes, the production values feel like a dress rehearsal for a student film; the grainy videotape transfer is for the birds, especially in today's digital age (I think the famous Patterson footage of Bigfoot has better definition, LOL); and the acting performances vary from respectable to don't-quit-your-day-job.  But Richard Boone is good as "Russian," as well as the young Stewart Petersen as "Sam Sutter," who feels responsible after his sister, "Charlotte," is abducted by Indians, practically right from his hands, ultimately unable to keep himself from trying to track her down, even without a clue how, especially after Sam's Dad, "John Sutter" (Clint Ritchie), tries but doesn't get far (those darn coyotes!).  But then Sam persuades Russian (who saves his life at the beginning of his journey) to join him in his desperate plight to save Charlotte, so the mission transfers to Sam's shoulders, but how can he and Russian bring Charlotte back alive when they're so outnumbered by the Indians?  The dramatic ending is like a Western/Native-American symbolic collaboration, with the filmmakers doing their best with what little resources they had, but is effective, nonetheless.  So, movie-makers, please keep in mind this good little movie with the potential for a great, high-quality Hollywood remake, whose story still has unfilled promise.
summary: Now here's a movie that may be the most deserving of a remake, unlike all those recent unnecessary remakes.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this movie for the first time on TV back in the 70s, apparently when it was first produced. Although I only vaguely remembered the entire movie (and couldn't even recall the name of it!) a little googling of some key phrases helped me track it down. Some funny catch phrases that were spoken by the crusty old prospector, and especially the dream-like, haunting conclusion (which is almost too mind-blowing for words), stuck with me through the years, compelling me to find it and see it again.This may not have been an A-list Hollywood production, but it dares to explore some unique and uncharted territory by making you reflect on just how far you might go to save something or someone that was dear to your heart, and shows how, so long as you go the extra mile and give it your very best shot, all things are possible and you just never know what fate might have in store.One is left at the end with the vague feeling that not everything has been satisfactorily explained and that some unanswered questions remain, but these questions pale into insignificance against the main point of the story. You simply cannot fail to be moved by it.

reviewText: This is a real fine Western.The story is intriguing and exceptionally well conceived.There is lots of action and the idea of a such a lost,or at least unknown tribe of Indians existing unbeknowns to anyone is novel to say the least.There are several exceptional roles ,but the role of an old Trapper,played by Richard Boone is fantastic.The story is set in the Moab National Park in Utah, where the scenery is out of this world.However,the photography quality of my DVD version is simply awful.Also ,the sound is nothing to write home about.It's obvious that other Reviewers feel the same.Hence many rate this movie very low because of the photography and sound quality while others rate it high for the storyline and action.I suspect the original film was excellent,and I still hold with my titleand rating.I would like to see this movie reissued because it far exceeds the Westerns coming out these days.
summary: They just don't make them like this anymore.

reviewText: I remember watching this movie for the first time when I was about 14 year old.  I am 31 now. I have two sisters and I would do the same thing for either one of them as Sam did for his sister.  It is true what Charlotte said at the beginning of the movie.  There is no greater love then to give your life for a friend.  At first Sam doesn't understand this concept, but after his sister is kidnapped by an unknown Indian tribe, he goes on a seemingly impossible and long dangerous journey to find her.  Once he does, a situation develops and he discovers in order to save her life, he must sacrifice his own.  It is a race against the sun (literally) in his attempt to save his sister.The ending scene was so powerful.  We learn just how far that great love for a friend can reach and in a way that you would never expect.  The realization of the power of that love will make your heart weep in joy and sadness.  Without giving more of the ending away, let me just say this, there are so many emotionally filled dynamics to the last scene, I cried like a baby.There is one reason why this movie does not get 5 stars.  If you have not seen the movie, I would stop reading at this point.  I cannot understand why Charlotte ended up pregnant by the man who kidnapped her.  Did Charlotte accept her new life with this tribe and over time, fell in love with him?  That was the impression I got.  I suppose in a real life situation, something like that can happen, it just bothered me.  I felt the movie could have done without that.  From a brother prospective, I would be so angry to know the man who took my sister away impregnated her.

reviewText: Terrible movie!Lousy script, lousy acting, lousy directing. The kid who was apparently the star of the movie, (he got second billing), was stiff and wooden. Some of the time he didn't seem to participate, like he was watching the movie instead of in it. The reason I watched it was because it had decent reviews and because of Richard Boone and he was awful, but I guess he didn't have much to work with. I'm very surprised about all the high ratings. What were you people smoking?I love westerns, but this was just a bad movie! If you want to see a good movie with this plot watch John Wayne's "The Searchers" from 1956. One of Wayne's best.A couple of other comments: Movie reviews should be about the movie, not "I'm giving it one star because I got a bad copy, or it arrived late, or it's the wrong region and I can't watch it". These comments don't have anything to do with the movie. If there's a problem note it, but don't rate the movie low because of a technical problem. Also Amazon has a habit of using the date the DVD was released as the Release Date. Who cares when the DVD was released, I want to know when the movie was made. For instance, "The Painted Desert" shows a release date of 2005, It was Clark Gable's first talkie. He died in 1960. Come on Amazon, you can do better.

Title: N/A

reviewText: Imagine a film made by people who have absolutely no talent at film-making -- acting, directing, writing, whatever -- and you'll have a good idea of what "Against a Crooked Sky" is like. It offers all the excitement of watching paint dry, without the pleasure of inhaling aromatic organics. You'll be glancing at your watch every 30 seconds, hoping it'll all be over before you suffer permanent brain damage.The only participant with any talent is Richard Boone, an accomplished and popular actor. But the script gives neither Boone (nor anyone else) anything interesting to say, so we wind up gazing at his sizable paunch. (I wouldn't be surprised if Boone made a stab at fixing the script's many problems, then abandoned it as hopeless.) At least the dog (B'ar Killer) is cute and makes adorable noises.If you want to fall asleep without the use of addictive drugs -- this is it.PS: I neglected to mention that Henry Wilcoxon was a generally respected actor and producer. Like Boone, he is definitely "slumming" in this film.
Title: N/A
